definition: King of the Olympian gods, ruler of the sky, lightning, thunder, law, order, and justice
myth: Zeus overthrew his father Cronus and divided the world with his brothers - he took the sky, Poseidon the sea, and Hades the underworld.

definition: The Feathered Serpent god of wind, air, and learning. Creator deity who brought knowledge to humanity
myth: Quetzalcoatl descended to the underworld to retrieve the bones of ancient humans and created the current race of people by sprinkling his own blood on them.

definition: God of mummification and the afterlife, protector of graves and guide to the underworld
myth: Anubis weighs the hearts of the deceased against the feather of Ma'at to determine their worthiness for the afterlife.

definition: The Destroyer and Transformer, one of the principal deities of Hinduism, part of the Trimurti
myth: Shiva performs the cosmic dance of destruction and creation called Tandava, which maintains the cycle of the universe.

definition: The Allfather, god of wisdom, poetry, death, divination, and magic. Ruler of Asgard
myth: Odin sacrificed his eye at Mimir's well to gain wisdom and hung himself on Yggdrasil for nine days to learn the secrets of the runes.

definition: Goddess of the sun and the universe, ruler of the heavens and ancestor of the Japanese imperial family
myth: When Amaterasu hid in a cave, plunging the world into darkness, the other gods lured her out with a mirror and dance.

definition: Phantom Queen, goddess of war, fate, and death. Often appears as a trio of sisters or a crow
myth: The Morrigan would fly over battlefields as a crow, choosing who would die and influencing the outcome of wars.

definition: Trickster god who takes the form of a spider, keeper of all stories and wisdom
myth: Anansi tricked the sky god Nyame into giving him ownership of all stories by capturing a python, hornets, and a leopard.

definition: God of sun, war, and human sacrifice. Patron deity of the Aztec capital Tenochtitlan
myth: Born fully armed from his mother Coatlicue, he immediately defeated his 400 siblings who tried to kill her.

definition: Goddess of wisdom, handicraft, and strategic warfare. Patron of the city of Athens
myth: Athena sprang fully grown and armored from the forehead of Zeus after he swallowed her pregnant mother Metis.

definition: God of wisdom, writing, hieroglyphs, science, magic, and the moon. Inventor of writing
myth: Thoth invented hieroglyphics and was the scribe who recorded the verdict when hearts were weighed in the afterlife.

definition: God of beginnings, wisdom, and remover of obstacles. Has an elephant head
myth: Shiva beheaded Ganesha not knowing he was his son, then replaced his head with an elephant's to bring him back to life.

definition: Trickster god of mischief, lies, and chaos. Shape-shifter who causes trouble for the gods
myth: Loki's children include the wolf Fenrir, the world serpent JÃ¶rmungandr, and Hel, goddess of the underworld.

definition: Creator deity who with his wife Izanami created the islands of Japan and many gods
myth: When Izanagi fled the underworld after seeing his dead wife's rotting form, the gods of purification were born from his cleansing ritual.

definition: Triple goddess of poetry, healing, and smithcraft. Associated with fire and spring
myth: Brigid's sacred flame at Kildare was tended by 19 priestesses and burned for over 1,000 years until the 13th century.

definition: Divine messenger and trickster, guardian of crossroads and doorways between worlds
myth: Eshu carries messages between humans and the Orishas. He must be honored first in any ritual or the prayers won't reach the gods.

definition: Smoking Mirror, god of night, sorcery, and the north. Rival of Quetzalcoatl
myth: Tezcatlipoca lost his foot when it was bitten off by the earth monster Cipactli during the creation of the world.

definition: God of the sea, storms, earthquakes, and horses. Brother of Zeus
myth: Poseidon created horses as a gift to impress Demeter and later gave Athena's city its first horse.

definition: Goddess of magic, motherhood, and wisdom. One of the most important deities in Egyptian mythology
myth: Isis reassembled the dismembered body of her husband Osiris and used magic to conceive their son Horus.

definition: The Preserver, maintains cosmic order. Has 10 avatars including Rama and Krishna
myth: Vishnu descends to Earth in different forms (avatars) whenever evil threatens to overwhelm good.

definition: Goddess of love, beauty, fertility, war, and death. Leader of the Valkyries
myth: Freya receives half of those who die in battle in her hall FÃ³lkvangr - the other half go to Odin's Valhalla.

definition: Storm god and sea god, brother of Amaterasu. Both heroic and troublesome
myth: Susanoo slew the eight-headed serpent Yamata no Orochi and found the legendary sword Kusanagi in its tail.

definition: Horned god of wild things, forests, fertility, and the underworld
myth: Depicted with antlers and surrounded by animals, Cernunnos represents the cycle of nature, death, and rebirth.

definition: Warrior goddess of winds, lightning, storms, death, and rebirth
myth: Oya guards the gates of cemeteries and is called upon to help souls transition to the afterlife.

definition: God of lightning, death, and the underworld. Twin brother of Quetzalcoatl with a dog head
myth: Xolotl guided the sun through the underworld each night and accompanied the dead on their journey.

definition: God of the dead and king of the underworld. Not evil, but stern and fair
myth: Hades abducted Persephone to be his queen, leading to the creation of the seasons when she must return each year.

definition: Sun god and king of the gods. Sails across the sky each day in his solar barque
myth: Each night Ra travels through the underworld and battles the chaos serpent Apophis to ensure the sun rises again.

definition: Goddess of time, creation, destruction, and power. Fierce protector against evil
myth: Kali emerged from Durga's forehead in battle and became so intoxicated with destruction that only Shiva could calm her.

definition: God of thunder, lightning, storms, strength, and protection of mankind
myth: Thor's hammer MjÃ¶lnir always returns to his hand after being thrown and can only be wielded by the worthy.

definition: God of the moon, born from Izanagi's right eye when he washed after leaving the underworld
myth: Tsukuyomi killed the food goddess Uke Mochi in disgust, causing his sister Amaterasu to never look at him again - separating day and night.

definition: Mother goddess and ancestor of the Tuatha DÃ© Danann, the supernatural race of Ireland
myth: The Tuatha DÃ© Danann, children of Danu, arrived in Ireland in clouds of mist and defeated the previous inhabitants.

definition: God of thunder, lightning, fire, and justice. Once a powerful king who became divine
myth: Shango was a mortal king who could breathe fire. After his death, he ascended to become an Orisha.

definition: God of rain, fertility, and water. Vital for agriculture in ancient Mexico
myth: Tlaloc's paradise Tlalocan was reserved for those who died by drowning, lightning, or water-related diseases.

definition: God of music, poetry, art, sun, light, knowledge, and healing
myth: Apollo slew the Python at Delphi and established his oracle there, the most important in ancient Greece.

definition: Lioness goddess of war, destruction, and healing. 'She who is powerful'
myth: Ra sent Sekhmet to punish humanity, but she became so bloodthirsty he had to trick her with beer dyed red to stop the slaughter.
